title: Homes taking an average of two weeks longer to sell
text:
The average time to sell a home has risen by nearly two weeks over the last year, as prices continue to fall in London and the South East.

A report by the Post Office showed homes across the UK are staying on the market for 114 days, or around three and a half months. This is up from 102 days past year.

Property experts have blamed uncertainty about the economy and concerns about Brexit for making many people nervous about buying a house, or making other big purchases.

Slowdown: A report by the Post Office showed homes across the UK are staying on the market for 114 days, or around three and a half months. This is up from 102 days last year

Homes in Oxford, one of the least affordable cities in the UK, took almost five months on average to shift – or 152 days.

In Aberdeen they sold in 151 days. Other long waits were in Middlesbrough (149), Slough (148), Blackpool (146) and London (138).

In contrast, owners in Edinburgh and Glasgow sold their homes quickest, with properties spending 45 and 47 days respectively on the market.

The report emerged as official figures showed house prices continue to fall in London and the South East, and rise in the North.

The Office for National Statistics said prices across the UK rose by 1.3 per cent in the year to August, up from 0.8 per cent in July, reaching £235,000 on average.

July's increase was the lowest since late 2012. In London, prices fell by 1.4 per cent year-on-year.

In contrast they rose 3.3 per cent in the North East and 3,1 per cent in the North West, 4.5 per cent in Wales and 1.6 per cent in Scotland.

Howard Archer, chief economic adviser at EY Item club, warned house prices could 'sink' around 5 per cent if the UK leaves the EU without a deal on October 31 or later.
